ygData.subject: Re: RAM problem using mixture equilibrate command
ygData.msgSnippet: Dr. Goodwin, I am having a similar problem with the ram in Matlab using equilibrate.  As I have discussed before, I am using several nested loops to calculate

Subject: Re: RAM problem using mixture equilibrate command
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211891685; y=FB_HannWKPxQefWenl9j-QpuA3yKmhzfQ3HoitloEmW4DOYaVw
X-Yahoo-Profile: csmnofbobs

Dr. Goodwin,
I am having a similar problem with the ram in Matlab using 
equilibrate.  As I have discussed before, I am using several nested 
loops to calculate the equilibrium molar mass of a gas mixture, then 
the time it takes to reach this molar mass, and then store the data 
and start the calculation over at a new initial temperature.  After 
about 5 temperature increments, equilibrate returns the error:

??? Unexpected Standard exception from MEX file.
What() is:bad allocation


Error in ==> @ThermoPhase\private\thermo_set at 13
  i = ctmethods(20, n,-job, a, b, c, d, e);  

Error in ==> ThermoPhase.equilibrate at 33
  iok = thermo_set(a.tp_id, 50, 101, solver, rtol, maxsteps, 
loglevel);

Error in ==> reactor1_equilibrium_HP at 44
   equilibrate(gas,'HP',1,1.0e-8,1000);


I am not quite sure what this means, but I then have to exit Matlab 
and reopen it to avoid the Matlab memory error message followed by a 
request to send my error report to the Mathworks support team.
I have tried to use the cleanup command, but I can't use the clear 
all command without losing the data I want to store, or resetting 
the loop variables.  I have tried using cleanup and individually 
clearing all of the variables except for the loop variables and the 
one storing my data, but it does not work.  Do you have any 
suggestions?  Would it be possible in future Cantera releases to 
modify the cleanup command so that the user can choose which C++ 
Cantera objects to delete?  
Thank you very much for any advise you can offer.
Jeff Miller






--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Perhaps this is a MATLAB problem. In MATLAB, there is no way that 
I can 
> find to delete the C++ Cantera object when the MATLAB 'shadow' 
object 
> is deleted (cleared).  So if you create lots of Cantera objects in 
the 
> MATLAB workspace, it can consume memory that is not released even 
if 
> you type 'clear all'.  I have provided a function 'cleanup' that 
> deletes ALL Cantera objects.  If you use 'cleanup', you must also 
clear 
> all Cantera objects from the MATLAB workspace, since they cannot 
be 
> used once the underlying C++ objects are deleted.
> 
> Or it could be a problem due to using MATLAB 6.5, since the 
Windows 
> Cantera MATLAB toolbox was compiled with MATLAB 7.
> 
> If MATLAB gives you problems, you could do your calculation in 
Python, 
> which has better capabilities for memory management.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> 
> On Jun 28, 2005, at 9:19 AM, chrtom1979 wrote:
> 
> > Dear Mr Goodwin,
> >
> > I finally manage to use the mixture equilibrate command (I work 
with
> > Matlab6.5 in Windows environment) using Cantera1.6. I work with a
> > powerful pc desktop (3.4GHz-Cpu, 1024MB-RAM), but I have some 
problem,
> > since the model fill up all the memory...
> > I work with an ideal gas phase and a solid carbon phase, doing 
some
> > iteration for several values of temperature and pressure.
> > I have seen in your Python demo (adiabatic.py) the following 
syntax:
> >
> > mix.equilibrate('HP', maxsteps = 1000,err = 1.0e-6, maxiter = 
200,
> > loglevel=0)
> >
> > where you fix the max number of iterations. There is a similar 
way to
> > do this in Matlab. I am not able to find it.
> >
> > Thank you in advance.
> > Your sincerly.
> >
> > Christian
